title: The Future of Crypto - Without Exchanges? - Eowyn Chen CEO, Trust Wallet

So let's talk about stable coins.

Bitcoin still commands a massive market cap, but if you look at something like Tether, it's a $150 billion market cap.

What are your general thoughts on on the stable coin landscape?
I think stablecoin is undoubtedly one of the tokens or one of the few tokens that find product market fit right viral product market fit.
Um, I think it has a lot to do in the historical context too when the treasury bills um uh interest rate are increasing uh starting from the covid time and or after the covid times and then it also solves one of the biggest problem within the industry about fluctuation and I think right now it becomes the most important uh bridge between crypto and trifi with so many traffic interests coming onto the crypto space.

Without stablecoin will be a lot harder.
Um, so I'm very bullish on stable coin and I think it's also politically at this moment that it gets the aha awakening moment uh outside of the crypto space to realize how important stable coin can be opportunity for them.
So it further fuels the institutional momentum coming in.
So I think that's fantastic.

I get to see a lot of retail opportunity.
And I I love doing retail businesses is because we get to see the pain points of the world earlier and faster.
Um, stablecoin got first adopted be besides trading is also because of the um the disadvantage of the world needs a better assets to hedge their uh fiat uh when it's coming down to the really terrible inflation moments.
Um, so it's actually where the debanked where the disadvantage are getting the stable coin into everybody people's hands a lot more.
Um, and um the data that I was seeing in last year September is that it was already a bull market but there were about $10 billion worth of USDT not moving for six months.
What does that mean?
It means that people coming down to crypto not because of the spec speculative reasons.
Yeah.
Um, they're not even thinking about whatever yields because it's not even moving.
It's just because people wanted to hold US dollar assets and then crypto provides this global access network that traditionally uh retail people or disadvantaged people deepbacked people cannot have access to and I think that's actually a very meaningful impact that stable coin had earlier even before all this political movement uh and realizations too um and that's that leads us to develop that product features uh to give users a earning opport opportunity besides holding stable coin.
Yeah.
Um, so we launched the stable coin earn that people can just deposit USDT, USDC, um USDA into the major chains and then earn four to six% of the yield without any lock up period of time.
Okay.
And I think this is a much more fantastic way to provide micro savings account banking services.
Yeah.
For the people that otherwise would not be able to afford the bank accounts.
Uh, in many of the countries.
Um, and then the adoption is also quite good.
Um, it's as expected the adoption mostly come from retail.
Mhm.
U not the major wells that you will imagine from the institutions.

Yeah.
And then this is accumulation of $50, $100, $200 those kind of a checks.
Yeah.
And that's what I find the adoptions and the impact that crypto can have in people's life is heartwarming.
Yeah, exactly.
I mean, I've I've had many conversations with Paulo Arduino from from Tether and uh he often talks about USDT not being important for Americans or Europeans, but for the rest of the world, developing countries, you know, countries that are facing hyperinflation and that sort of thing.
They're looking to the US dollar and a few other harder currencies.
They're all fiat currencies, but they're still a better store of value than their local currency.
And finally, we have infrastructure rails that allow them to do that.
And that is why you're seeing this.

Where do you get the yield from?
And and how do you do that?

So far we use a completely decentralized way to plug into the uh DeFi protocol yields.
Um, but those are very good partners that we work with that truly holds up the security and the compliance standards.
Ave and the likes or a few other players.
Yes Moro, a uh compounds.
Yeah, they're all kind of the ones that already survive the the ups and downs of the markets and figure out the sustainable path to it.
Um, but I know that there are lots of other opportunity to potentially plug in offchain yield uh that potentially can allow this stable coin to be able to power real economy.
Um, there are a lot of teams that I'm know that are kind of building things around it, but we will wait for them to mature a little bit more so that they can plug into the systems.
With regards to the regulations, I think stablecoin is definitely one of the product that you want to have regulatory clarity to be able to unlock and connect to more payment channels opportunities into the real life for people.
Uh in this conferences there are lots of conversations around the payments and then be able to build on top of the stable coin and then only stable coin as the cornerstone gets the regulatory clarity.
Then there are more traffic product on top of it.
Uh that can feel not shaky, right?
Like for for the fundamental realize on the stable coin that they have to be anchored on.
Um so I think this is pretty bullish.
Uh and to be honest, US dollar uh besides US dollar, I guess it's euro are probably going to be the top two currency fiat currency assets that stable coin format will be adopted the most.
So, it's good to see the US government leading in the way uh and uh uh setting the setting the tone so that hopefully Europe can follow.
Yeah, I hope so, too.
Um I think one of the big sort of topics that I've been exploring of late is, you know, self-custody versus custody solutions.
You've got big centralized exchanges.
A lot of people just leave a lot of value on exchanges and for the most part, you should be fine, right?
There's a there's a lot of protections in place that are that are pretty decent, but at the same time, bad things happen.
You look no further than the Bybit hack earlier this year.
Social engineering, their their systems get compromised and they drain $1.4 billion from an Ethereum hot wallet.
That's one of the biggest exchanges.
It's just a stark reminder.
If you keep if you trust your coins to someone else, you are trusting them to look after your money.
It's the same thing as you put it in a bank account.
If there's a run on the banks and and they're not managing their deposits properly, there's a risk.
This is why things like Trust Wallet exist, right?
Yes.
Maybe you can just talk a little bit more about your philosophy on self custody, what the difficulties still are.
There's a lot of responsibility on the user and what the trade-offs are of that and why you think that most people should use something like Trust Wallet over something else.
Yeah, one of our mission is to provide people the freedom to own and the freedom to access opportunities which is what we believe as the fundamental value proposition that why we come into the space and I think freedom to own is so important philosophically because as we age we start to rely on so many intermediary that we even lose the capabilities or use the confidence that you truly own something like looking at your fiat dollars on the bank account right like how do you really make sure that that's your bank account?
What if someone made a database problems and then you can get wiped out and and I guess that those are the points where you don't have confidence that you truly own it.
Hence you in you you introduce regulations monitories to be able to hold accountability uh on the ones that can control it.
But who knows whether there is black black swan event and that's why I think self- custody is very important is because people should always have the option that they can own it themselves.
Yeah.
Sometimes with a given my American background I use the analogy as the US's second amendments which is the rights to own a gun.
I know that it's not very common for the rest of the world to have this opportunity but the reason why it is such an important fundamental constitutional rights in the US is because that yes you're not going to use your gun every day as a convenience for you to guard your security.
You will trust the police.
You will trust the army to provide the security as a service and the infrastructure.
But what if one day you're in this countryside, you need to guard your own safety.
You got to have your means to say, I can own it.
I can protect myself.
And I think it's the same thing with self- custody.
I will be very honest.
I don't think self- custody is for everybody in all situations at all times.
